Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation2: A noise complaint is reported due to a late-night party disturbing neighbors
Story: I sat in my patrol car, the radio crackling with the address of the noise complaint. My heart sank as I recognized it—my own family’s house. Tonight was our annual celebration, a tradition passed down for generations, and my parents had reminded me all week how important it was to keep our customs alive. As I pulled up, I could see the lights, hear the laughter, and smell the familiar food drifting through the air. My badge felt heavy on my chest. As a police officer, I was expected to enforce the law, to be impartial and fair, even if it meant shutting down my own family’s party. But as a child, I was expected to honor my family, to protect our traditions, and not bring shame or disappointment. I could already imagine the looks on their faces if I walked in as an officer instead of a son. The weight of both uniforms pressed down on me, and I sat frozen, torn between duty and devotion, unable to move.
